item.title: Plymouth shooting: Gunman's mother among five victims named
item.description: Jake Davison murdered his mother Maxine before shooting and killing four other people.

item.title: Afghanistan: Boris Johnson defends UK's role amid evacuation
item.description: Boris Johnson says there is "no military solution" to the situation as the Taliban advances.

item.title: Police officer and child found dead in Kidderminster
item.description: The deaths in Kidderminster are being treated as unexplained, West Mercia Police says.

item.title: Banksy confirms East Anglian seaside artwork is genuine
item.description: The secretive artist claims responsibility for the pieces along England's east coast.

item.title: Lord of the Rings: Amazon moves show to UK from New Zealand
item.description: The multi-million dollar production is one of the most expensive shows in the history of television.

item.title: Kadian Nelson: Man who raped girl on her way to school jailed
item.description: Kadian Nelson was chased away during the attack after a 10-year-old girl saw him snatch his victim.

item.title: Daniela Espirito Santo reported partner to police seven times before death
item.description: Daniela Espirito Santo, from Grantham, was not failed by police, a watchdog says.

item.title: Esther Dingley: Hiker's Pyrenees death an accident, police say
item.description: Sources say it is unclear what caused her to fall but her boots may have been unsuitable for ice.

item.title: Apple regrets confusion over 'iPhone scanning'
item.description: The iPhone-maker will introduce tools that can detect child sex abuse images uploaded to iCloud.

item.title: Afghan war: Kabul's young women plead for help as Taliban advance
item.description: They feel abandoned by the democratic world they thought they were part of, writes Yalda Hakim.

item.title: Covid: Record your cough to help improve detection, says government
item.description: The government wants people to send in samples of themselves breathing, coughing and reading aloud.

item.title: Adam Peaty: I'm going to be very uncomfortable on Strictly
item.description: The Olympic champion is the latest to be announced for the show.

item.title: 'Hip hip hooray, it's the Burryman's Day'
item.description: The quirky parade features a man walking through South Queensferry covered from head to ankles in burrs.

item.title: Back to school triggers US fury over masks for students
item.description: With Covid cases rising, Americans are divided over how students should return to the classroom.

item.title: Car in near-miss with train on Cumbria level crossing
item.description: CCTV footage shows the car driving across the barrierless crossing in front of the Northern train.

item.title: Satanic forums visited by a killer uncovered
item.description: The BBC uncovers evidence about Satanic forums visited by the killer of two sisters.

item.title: TV newsreader Victoria Derbyshire overcomes on-air shoe struggle
item.description: The BBC News channel presenter was seen quietly cursing as she struggled to put on her high heels.

item.title: Virtual reality: 'There's no max, there's no limit!'
item.description: "There's no max, there's no limit" to virtual reality, so is it the future of live music?

item.title: Nick Grimshaw on leaving Radio 1: 'I've interviewed everyone, twice'
item.description: The legendary presenter reflects on leaving BBC Radio 1 after 14 years.

item.title: Northern Turkey hit by severe flash flooding
item.description: Seventeen people have reportedly died, with more than 1,400 people evacuated from the areas affected.

item.title: Coda: 'Deafness is not a costume you can put on,' says film director
item.description: The maker of the film Coda says being authentic to the story of child with deaf parents was vital.

item.title: How anti-vaxxers are living and loving in a Covid world
item.description: Opponents of Covid vaccines are turning to online dating and house shares for the unvaccinated only.

item.title: The fiendish new trick cyber-criminals are using to evade capture
item.description: Bitcoin researchers discover a new darknet tool criminals are using to help launder their digital money.

item.title: Can Americans pull the plug on petrol-powered cars?
item.description: Joe Biden wants half of all cars sold in the US to be zero emission by 2030 - but getting there won't be easy.

item.title: How can new technology protect outdoor workers?
item.description: Working outdoors in extreme heat can be deadly, new tech and better protection for workers could help.

item.title: Berlin embassy arrest: A case of old-school spying?
item.description: Why nothing in the case of the arrest of a man at the British Embassy in Berlin should surprise us.

item.title: Afghanistan war: Taliban back brutal rule as they strike for power
item.description: Afghanistan's ex-rulers still back brutal punishments, the BBC finds as it goes behind Taliban lines.

item.title: Burns falls late to check England rally against India
item.description: England's spirited fightback in the second Test against India is checked by the loss of Rory Burns late on the second day.

item.title: Premier League: 'One signing could decide the title race, but it's not Harry Kane' - Alan Shearer
item.description: Joining Manchester City would be a brilliant move for Harry Kane - but it would not mean the Premier League title race is all over, says MOTD pundit Alan Shearer.

item.title: It would be 'tragic' if GB relay team lose silver medals, says British Olympic chief
item.description: It is "tragic" that CJ Ujah's relay team-mates could lose their silver medals as a result of the sprinter's anti‑doping rule violation, says the British Olympic Association chairman.

item.title: Arsenal's Willock completes Newcastle move
item.description: Newcastle have completed the signing of Arsenal midfielder Joe Willock on a six-year deal.

item.title: Plymouth shooting: Who can own a firearm or shotgun in the UK?
item.description: A shooting in Plymouth which left six people dead has put the focus on who can own a gun in the UK.

item.title: A visual guide to what happened
item.description: A gunman shot and killed five people in Plymouth before turning the gun on himself. Here's what we know about how events unfolded.

item.title: Incels: A new terror threat to the UK?
item.description: Is the incel belief system followed by Jake Davison, the Plymouth gunman, a terror threat to the UK?

item.title: The investigation so far
item.description: Police and forensic teams are searching multiple crime scenes after five people were killed.

item.title: Shooting 'a truly shocking event' say police
item.description: Devon and Cornwall Police Chief Constable Shaun Sawyer explains how reports of the shootings came in.

item.title: Plymouth Shootings: Home Secretary says many questions to be asked
item.description: Home Secretary Priti Patel says she'll be looking for answers about the shootings that left six dead.

item.title: Plymouth MP: Community 'trying to make sense' of shooting
item.description: MP Luke Pollard says the community is pulling together in the face of the "deeply grim" news.

item.title: Plymouth shooting: Inside the dark world of 'incels'
item.description: Who are the angry young men who describe themselves as "involuntarily celibate"?

item.title: Plymouth shooting: Defence Secretary rules out terrorism
item.description: Defence Secretary Ben Wallace said the shooting in Plymouth was ''a very sad and tragic event''.

item.title: Plymouth shooting: Forensic investigators at the scene
item.description: Police cordoned off the area and said that the situation has been contained.

item.title: Afghanistan: Desperation as thousands flee the Taliban
item.description: Yogita Limaye reports from a camp in Kabul where thousands who have been displaced by violence seek refuge.

item.title: Afghanistan: How the Taliban gained ground so quickly
item.description: The situation looks bleak for the Afghan government, but there may still be a chance of a stalemate.

item.title: Life in a town taken by the Taliban in Afghanistan
item.description: BBC correspondent Secunder Kermani reports from a town in Afghanistan recently taken by the Taliban

item.title: Mapping the advance of the Taliban in Afghanistan
item.description: Maps of Afghanistan show who controls districts in fighting between the government and Taliban forces.

item.title: Afghanistan: Why is there a war?
item.description: As foreign forces pull out after 20 years of war, what did it achieve and what happens next?

item.title: Afghanistan war: Do the Taliban want to conquer or compromise?
item.description: The BBC speaks to two high profile figures in its chain of command who have very different messages.

item.title: Covid rules: What's changing in Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate, which workers are exempt and what if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: The rules in England and Northern Ireland will change from Monday 16 August.

item.title: Covid: What will school be like in the new term?
item.description: Pupils across the UK are preparing to return to school after the summer holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: What do we know about the artemisia plant?
item.description: Artemisia plant extracts have anti-malarial properties, but there's no evidence they can combat Covid-19.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: UK holidays: What are the rules?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The government has announced that 16 and 17-year-olds will receive the Covid vaccine.

item.title: Wildfires: How Portuguese club Tondela drove through the flames
item.description: In Tondela, the bond between club and fans was at its strongest during the night in October 2017 when nobody slept.

item.title: Malta: The teenagers pulled from the sea and accused of terrorism
item.description: How three teenagers rescued from the Mediterranean Sea ended up in Malta accused of terrorism.

item.title: ‘If only I’d found out earlier I had pelvic congestion syndrome’
item.description: Sophie Robehmed suffered from back and stomach pains for years before being diagnosed with PCS.
